headline: Organisation Structure
pros: American Express (UK) looks after its employees extremely well. Type of health insurance, support and other benefits can be one of the best in the industry. Company can contribute up to 11% pension if you contribute 7%. Not many companies do this. They would pay good bonus and pay rise if you have done well in your performance ratings. Also, company performance is taken into consideration when adjudicating bonuses. Flexible work pattern (working from home) exists and some people can apply to work from home 100% time - sometimes it is granted. There are opportunities to learn additional skills and you'll be supported by your manager well in this.
cons:
Beware of various bands within Amex. This is somehow kept secret to outsiders. Ask the recruiters - what is the job band for the role that you are applying. It (job band information) won't appear in public job board - only available in internal job board.
If you have several years of experience, you still may be applying for Band30 which is a junior position. A senior (manager) position is Band 35. It is almost impossible to get promoted from B30 to B35 unless you are engineer (software developer). B40 are called Directors. B45 starts at Vice President (4). VP III, VP II are also there. B70 is called usually Senior Vice President or Country Manager. Next level up is Executive VP. Next is President and then C roles. 
There is no automatic progression or promotion within Amex. For each role, you have to apply and unless you have something called great "networking", i.e. you have the sponsorship of influential people, you can forget about promotion. There may be exceptions but this is how it generally works. 
It does not matter what is your annual performance - best performance won't give you promotion. The only way is - you impress your leader by agreeing to everything they say and then they internally open a role and promote you. If you are not in the good book of your "leader" i.e., line manager, nothing will happen and you may have to look for jobs elsewhere if you want to be promoted or earn more money.
Some "leaders" can be jealous and try to block subordinates to be promoted as best they can. However, American Express should not be judged by the bad behaviours of minority (leaders), but you still need to be mindful of this situation.

headline: Unrealistic Metrics & YOU ARE REQUIRED TO DO SALES
pros: Good pay, good benefits, free clinics.
cons:
This is a high turnover rate job. They will sweet talk about this company during your interview & training, & they gonna make you feel like you "found the ideal job and you're so lucky you landed here." But honey, they repeat this every month to every different batch of newbies coz mark my word, people leave after 3 months. 
At some point, Customers' screaming, yelling, cursing, and crying is not an issue for you anymore coz there's something more stressful coming your way...the metrics. The leaders are going to ask you why the calls are too long, why didn't you extend your "SALES", why did the customer call back (even though they called back coz of different reasons). Even if you feel sick and needed to take some off days to heal up, they will make you sign a paper saying you promise to take care of your health and not get sick again. They micromanage you to the point that you can't even pee. If you missed your break time coz some calls are too long or uncontrollable, you CAN'T replace the break time you lost, and also get a backlash about not taking the break on time. 
They question you for 1 bad review from a customer instead of acknowledging you for the other 10 Excellent customer reviews you had. (just an example). They will do anything to bring the mood down really.

headline: Best company benefits
pros: Best company I have ever worked for in my entire life. They really do back you all the way and make sure that every part of our lives is stable. When my uncle passed away and brother got thrown into jail they paid me in full and gave me compassionate leave as well. I had covid and was taken into a quarantine center by the government and American Express covered me in full. When it came to looking after me they really went above and beyond.
cons: I didn’t enjoy the pressure of the job as we have to answer anything from 40 to 60 calls per day/shift and sometimes even up to a 100 calls. I started to feel a shift in my mood after talking to all these people that were of course calling in due to their financial frustration but I learnt a lot from this role. And the part I did not enjoy at all was working Night Shift. That was brutal. I also had to work my weekends and felt my days and nights were completely upside down.

headline: Nepotism and Lack of Accountability Undermine a Good Company
pros:
Work life balance is actually practiced
Good place to coast along unless you upset people
Very honest and transparent business practices
cons: It is a large company, slow moving and decision making is by consensus. People who move ahead are those that ruffle feathers the least and have the right connections. Risk taking is genuinely avoided. This leads to unqualified and inept people, who are part of the family, moving into leadership positions. Senior leaders are part of an old guard, they make many mistakes , setting direction first, then giving up, then setting a different direction, with no accountability. The story inside is that it's not lack of accountability at Amex, it is just slow accountability, which is a terrible confession to make. No significantly successful new business idea in the last 10 years.

headline: Stagnation and limited opportunities
pros: The people you work with are great. Teams do work well together once you get used to al of them. That can be a bit hard when you are first learning. The benefits are solid, but not great. In light of the pandemic, they have made changes that are good.
cons:
You cannot grow and gain skills in your role. If you want to move forward in the company, you need to do trainings on everything. There's no hands-on experience. There's no desire to up-skill employees. Senior Management wants everyone to be the same type of manager and worker. When you want or try to do thing differently, they tell you to stop. There's fear of trying new things and taking a chance on someone. Instead, it's all about playing it safe.

Things take way too long to complete, with some exceptions. For some projects, you need to have 3-4 teams involved in the decision process. That's not efficient. Everyone is stuck in back to back meetings all day. Processes are inefficient. There is never enough time or people to get work done. You always seem to be on a small and mighty team trying to do the work of a large team. Based on how projects are run, there's never an end game. There's never a light at the end of the tunnel.

headline: Soulless
pros:
Before covid the workload was managable and you could leave early.

If you have zero talent, you're fine.
cons:
Making high sales gets you zero reprieve, and they will just expect more and more. If your numbers ever drop despite being better than your team, they'll make it seem like you're the one slacking.

Because of covid and cancellations and everything else the government does, the job is incredibly busy. It is nonstop calls from 10am to 9pm. Seriously, nonstop.

They will badger you if you spend a minimum of 1 minute longer on your breaks or sign in late by 1 minute.

They live in this delusional world where their job is so great and so fun but everyone can't wait to leave.

Teammates will sabotage you with responsibilities so they can leave when scheduled. 

They had manual overtime for several months and likely still do.

I left every day mentally exhausted/numb. I never felt challenged, appreciated or inspired.

The workforce is very diverse, so long as you define diverse as female.

Way too many responsibilities. 

Calls are incessant and every booking you make you have to babysit every day and make sure there aren't issues from the vendor.

It's entirely too much work and if they aren't robbing you of your bonuses by writing you up for non-customer-related-things, the money you do get is not worth it.

If you don't need money you can't tell them you need a break. You'll be worked until you snap and then they'll blame you.

headline: Please do not work for this company
pros: At the end of the day there are no pros.
cons:
When I started working for this company, they painted a very pretty picture. The training took 90 days and we had to certify to be able to move forward with the job. 

First of all, the metrics and requirements to certify are RIDICULOUS. Out of a class of 8, only 3 people certified…. What do you think that means… Hmm. 
The card members are EXTREMELY RUDE and if you say something they do not agree with they will refuse to get off of the phone until they speak to a supervisor which will never happen because your leader or coaches will NOT speak to cardmembers. So.. you’re stuck on the phone with a very angry cardmember who ends up insulting you. After that, the leaders will find a way to blame it on you for not de-escalating the situation even though it was completely unavoidable. 
The pay may seem good at first but for everything you need to do, it is ABSOLUTELY not enough. You will be doing the work for 3 different departments but only getting paid for one job. 
Since 5 of the 8 did not certify, they were laid off. Which is so ridiculous to me. All of the trainees were extremely intelligent and did a much better job that any other department. I attest to that. This company is a complete joke and the worst and most stressful job I have ever had in my life.

headline: A large company with all the pros and cons that come with
pros:
Great work life balance with very flexible working arrangements depending on your team (in-office, hybrid, full WFH).

Relatively competitive compensation compared to peers. Decent annual raises and bonus targets.

Fairly modern tech stacks.

High spec’d work laptops to do whatever needs to be done (usually MBPs). WFH and in-office peripherals are also very good.

Internal movement between teams with leader’s approval.

Open, welcoming engineering culture with many common-interest slack channels.
cons:
A lot of red tape and antiquated processes, though this is improving and is probably much better than our peers in financial services.

Kind of political. Larger raises and promotions in title tend to happen with one foot out the door, offer in hand. Leaders can attempt to block internal moves.

Hiring process can be confusing and slow.

Reorgs happen with little/no notice.

headline: BE CAREFUL! It's a place before retiring or parental leave.
pros:
- If you are looking to retire soon and coming closer to the end of your working career or need a decent parental leave, it's a great place. Allows working from home most of the time.

- Either you are left alone, but it also means lack of support, or it will be an extreme case of micromanagement, but they call it support.

- The NEW HIRE salary is only ok for a year or two. The longer you stay in the company, the further away from the newest hire's salary since they pay more than existing employees. Generally, it's the lowest PAY in the industry.
cons:
- Clients are just a number! The company doesn't care about the long-term. See for yourself.

- UNETHICAL sales tactics and UNBELIEVABLE internal red tapes.

- AT YOUR OWN RISK, LACKS JOB STABILITY. Middle management is safe for a year or two. However, Senior Manager/Executive/VP/GM are generally the first to get redundancy packages when there is a cost-cutting measure. If you are in a sales position (non-leadership role), you have about 6 months to 1 year to prove yourself to stay in the job. Reducing sales pipeline and your target DOUBLES each year!

- Slow career progression. Only when there is an opportunity is when someone goes to a competitor. There are many internal politics at play and behind curtain deals. They already have brought someone from other business segments to fill in the space. However, for hiring compliance reasons, they would advertise the role and interview others just for the sake of it. So don't expect any career and personal development.

- Most leaders lack skills, experience and knowledge compared to other competitors.

- It was only bearable before the pandemic, during COVID, and now, the company has no strategic direction. TARGETS are unrealistic, and there are no exceptions.

headline: Amazing culture. Tech is very US-centric.
pros: Amex has great culture & great people. Almost all colleagues are genuinely committed to doing the right thing for colleagues and customers. Most leaders are committed to working flexibly & supporting personal growth.
cons:
If you are considering a UK Tech role, don’t underestimate how US-centric most things are.  With most of tech in Phoenix, cross time zone collaboration can be difficult at times.

Amex has an obsession with what band/grade people are. Never seen anything like it, including UK public sector. While it is recognised, there doesn’t seem to be any appetite to change.

Another thing that I observed within technology was the promotion of high-performing individuals into leadership positions, without the necessary support and mentoring to help them develop leadership skills. This doesn’t not seem to be the case in other areas of the business.

headline: Great Benefits and HR Policies but Politics undermine benefits
pros: American Express offers great perks and its HR policies make the organization a great place to work for. Senior Management generally does a good job in prioritizing long-term success before short-term results. Amex strongly encourages employees in participating in activities that benefit communities, for example with the campaign Give2Gether
cons: Workplace politics dilute the good reputation American Express gains from its virtues. It's hard to correlate an employees' advancement in career to his/her deliverables or dedication. In recent years, Amex laid off many tenured peoples' leaders and replaced them with relatively young members in its endeavor to attract young talent. That has led to a less friendly environment and many senior/tenured members feel insecure about their jobs.

headline: Musical chairs & red tape
pros: Company culture is earnest in establishing its core values for diversity and inclusion, incorporating it in mandatory employee training and hosting special events. WFH once or twice was allowed before the pandemic, and they have made efforts to review what other supports can be given to employees since then. At managerial level, this is a place to learn as much as you can to grow at a rapid rate, but you must accept the workload and stress that comes with it.
cons: Lots of turnover. There is equally as many people holding roles for a year on average before leaving for competitors or people who leave after several years at Amex without promotion. All projects are intensely scrutinized by legal team, which drags out timelines and has a direct impact on requirements. Salary seems to be lower than other financial industry competitors.

headline: You cannot find a better WLB at the same compensation

Innovations usually happen in M&A or VC part of the company (buy startups instead of launching risky features directly), not in your day to day work. (If you happen to join the startup team in Amex, you won't be able to enjoy the great WLB)
Unclear career path on manger level - there's no IC upside ladder, you have to move to leadership path if you want to go up - therefore tech/ analytical skills are not that valued compared to communication or upper management. (this is biggest issue)
tradeoff - No RSUn and only a very modest profit sharing into your 401k account... salary quite not comparable to other fintech... but you also work less hours....

headline: Good Culture , Learning & Opportunities
pros:
Benefits, Learning opportunities and forums, Senior Leadership.
Diverse cultures and Lot of processes in place to ensure Diversity and Inclusion.
cons:
Middle level management is like a lottery. There are lot of micro cultures within every organization largely depends on the how the respective VP leads that org. You can have a very good feeling or worst feeling working for Amex depending on where you landed and the kind of VP you work under.

There seems to be lot of fear of retaliation across as many i spoke to during my tenure expressed it. Though they see things are terribly going wrong or being treated bad, people hesitate to report it to next level leadership.

headline: Don’t work here
pros: There are absolutely no pros
cons: Most of management is clueless about the issues customers are angry about and frankly they don’t care. Customers that spend more money on their card are treated better than others. The company is morally bankrupt. Employees are treated like indentured servants. No flexibility on schedules, PTO, etc. They even dictate when you can use your Paid Sick time ..they seem to think people can control or predict when they will be sick. Team leaders have no accountability…mine was always making a smoothie, getting coffee, cooking dinner , or dealing with children when I needed assistance. When she was available she was unable to grasp the issue I needed help with and I had to spend call handle time explaining it to her. headline: Join if you’d like to ruin your life
pros:
1. Nobody bothers you outside working hours
2. Decent money (only if you’re just starting)
3. Brand name
cons:
1. People here only care about the business and not 1% about their employees. They would sweet talk and potray themselves as extremely professional and the sweetest most understanding people on the planet, but are the exact opposite.
2. Every single employee I’ve know for the 5 years is extremely frustrated and if only working there because they’ve got no other choice.
3. Growth is slower than a turtle walking
4. They make you work like donkeys and pay you pennies 
5. Most of the managers hardly appreciate the work you do. They’re only best at pointing out your flaws
6. One of the worst parts of the job is they’d make you work at unnatural hours, completely disregarding something known as the body clock! One month you’d be doing an early morning shift and it would take a 360 degree turn and you would get a crazy graveyard shift the very next month. Instead of a gradual transition, they would just suddenly throw the next shift at you. 
7. Probably the only organisation where you aren’t allowed to reschedule breaks. You miss your ‘15 min’ break, your fault, even if you’re helping customers. And you sit for hours and hours without taking breaks. 
8. The work is so monotonous, you’d want to kill yourself. The same thing every single day. No learning, no growth opportunities, nothing new to look up to.
9. Absolute disregard for mental health. 90% of the top tier managers don’t even know what terms like ‘therapy’ is. And ironically they have a wellness program.
10. You try to give them feedback, they’ll turn it back on you, make it your fault and you can do nothing about it. We’ve been told to give anonymous feedbacks, but somehow these ‘anonymous’ feedbacks reach the leadership and they would make your life living hell thereafter. 
11. The attrition rate in this organisation is sky high, but they still have the audacity to tell people to ‘just leave if you can’t work’ without and inch of shame.

headline: American Express - Great place but scope for improvement
pros:
1. Great place to work and a wonderful work culture. 
2. The organization takes very good care of its employees, medical benefits, bereavement leaves, flexible work timings etc. 
3. Treats in the form of food and goodies are common. 
4. The physical offices have great ambience and a very well thought seating area and environment to make work productive. 
5. The toilets, cafeteria, breakout areas are all very well maintained.
6. You have ample opportunity for growth (learning opportunities are immense).
cons:
1. Clear difference between Indian Managers and the ones outside.
Some of the ones in India have a Boss(them) to Slave or Servant (you) mentality. It's sick and a mental harassment. 
2. Salary raise is on the lower end and vertical movements can be slow unless you have Tier 1 college education or certifications (that can cost of thousands really).
3. Reporting an older employee (some of them are fossils here, 15 years+ in the org.) for unacceptable behavior in almost sure to have ill effects for you. They claim to be transparent and that it has no impact on the reporting party but its far from reality.

headline: Overworked and underpaid
pros: Dental care, maternity and day off for moving

There is an auto answer phone system which was brought in while working from home with no regard to personal living situations. All the team leaders concentrate on is agent availablity and not loosing calls. There is no support for the actual job as the team leaders do not even know how to use the systems. There was a reduncency scare during the pandemic which saw many talented and tenured individuals leave. The travel and lifestyle team is now so understaffed it's unbearable working conditions. New employees are currently in training and will be expected to hit the ground running. The Membership Manager position is a joke and card members no longer receive the personal service they once did. There are no suppliers for anything and most of the time agents are just googling answers for Card Members. There is a pay for performance bonus scheme which makes no sense. When you question it you get beat down. Some months you could get £1.00 or £200. If you don't agree with something you are basically treated so badly that your only option is to leave.

Basically the dream sold to you by their amazing brand for hiring, just does not stand up. Atleast won't if you are from Tier1 universities. 
 
Too much diversity push!
Promotions have baseline tenure criteria. Then your ratings (which is honestly a funny system). Then how well you might know people. Then if you are a diverse candidate or not. Merit might take a backseat at times here, diversity is more important for their brand. 
Eg. If the bar for a position is to obtain 70/100 points, and if you fetch 96/100 you might still be rejected for a 'diverse' candidate with 71/100 points. Not sure if this culture is good or bad for the company, but it is sure ah not good for many employees. 

*diverse means : females, and other lower represented groups. In India, it only means one, guess which one!

headline: Really lovely and genuine company, but slow paced
pros:
- Relaxed atmosphere
- Company genuinely cares about its colleagues and Cardmembers
- Great company for people with families
- You can stay in the company 20 years and do 10 very different jobs - there's lots of variety between roles
- Company genuinely cares about inclusion and diversity - feels like a very safe place to work. Inclusion and diversity policies do not feel tokenistic unlike a lot of other companies.
- CEO leads the company with vision and compassion, especially through Covid 19 - the company didn't make a single colleague redundant in 2020 through the crisis
- Some very capable engineers here who are also very willing to help you grow - even engineers in other teams will always make the time for you if you need technical expertise, mentorship or a general chat
- 9-5 is standard for engineers unless you're at director level
cons:
- Tech salary isn't that competitive compared to other London based financial services companies
- Departments are often siloed and change can be fairly slow paced - if you want a fast moving and agile tech company, Amex is probably not for you

headline: "Awesome" place to build your career with a toxic team culture
pros: Amazing brand, well-packaged benefits, great opportunities for new employees. Extremely competitive environment. It's an excellent place to grow your career from start if you're competitive and ambitious, but not empathetic.
cons:
It's nearly impossible to succeed in the engineering director role if you're hired from an outside firm. Amex has a cut-throat competitive culture, constant chase for numbers, lack of attention to individual colleague's needs. Many Directors are required to lead often times upwards of 30 people without the ability to re-structure the reporting relationship. Consultants are mainly treated as numbers, however full-time colleagues enjoy significant benefits, such as 6-month child-care leave, while the rest of the team is expected to pull the burden of delivery.
The leadership expects innovation and delivery of exceeding outcomes at every step of the way, beating your past numbers is not rewarded, it's expected - personal sacrifices that mid-level leaders make to keep the team spirit up and deliver on these needs often do not matter. Every month engineering has some kind of a competition and there are numerous favorites on multiple teams that persistently winning the game, while no one cares about specific people. It's all about the numbers. Budget decisions drive every major decision. Very few team members have significant tenures unless they're in a competitive senior leadership roles.

headline: Not what it is hyped up to be
pros: We got to work from home for over a year due to the pandemic. Remote work stations were mailed to us. The vacation time was great.
cons: When I quit, my bonus from previous year was taken back from my 401k. The management are forced to be micro-managers. My department handled disputes and fraud, but we were constantly given calls from other departments and held to higher call handling standards. It was impossible to stay in great standing. CFR is pushed down everyone's throat, but for a Platinum card that has a fee, it's a shame that workers are negatively impacted when a customer has to call back whether it is related to the prior call or NOT. The breaks are too short. When I quit, I didn't get an exit interview. I was a number and it showed. So many loyal great employees quit because of stress by the company-not the customer/job description. In my position of almost 3 years, there hasn't been NOT one shift bid. I had a terrible schedule from training and I hadn't had the opportunity to change it. I worked double weekends for close to 3 years with young children at home. The benefits were too expensive.

headline: Worst company I’ve ever worked for
pros: I honestly don’t understand how this place wins best company to work for awards. There are no pros. This has been an awful experience. For starters, there is absolutely ZERO work life balance. I start my day at 7:30am because I’m on calls with the India team and then I’m expected to work until 8pm because I’m so behind on work. Your manager is also in meetings all day long so don’t expect to get to meet with them ever. However they will take time out of their day to ask you to do 2 more things for them.
cons: They froze merit increases in 2020!!!!!!! We worked our butts off in 2020 and then didnt get a merit increase and our bonuses were slashed too. It may seem fun to move around to a new position every 2 years but when the team is constantly changing and you’re constantly getting a new manager because people are moving in and out of rolls it doesn’t become as fun as it seemed. The hours are long, the work is hard, and the reward is minimal. I wouldn’t recommend this place to anyone.

headline: Alert... I would think twice if you value what's right for the client vs. Company
pros: Benefits- (Retirement, Medical, educational, other), many changes in positions(due to a lot of reasons, potential for promotion, but low retention within company teams).Management in SVP titles and above are trying to change. Company is very vocal on Diversity/Inclusion.
cons:
1)I left the company in High Balance Credit due to company told me that I could not escalate calls that 2 clients were being pushed aside and not getting help. 2) Tracy -TL escalated these to VP and director and HR, They agreed that I shouldn't have escalated call for client trying to cover over violating a clients 
 credit rights to to Credit Acts and Violations. 3)Three-of-three new mothers who were promised the 22 weeks of Maternal Pay in the 2.5 yrs I was there, all had issues with getting paid on-time and were not instructed properly initially on how to submit by HR then told it was their fault for not submitting correctly(while away after the fact). 4) Different area's like in-Customer service are worried about Their CFR metrics then helping the client, In-Credit more worried about their ACM metrics then helping the clients, 96.5 % of the time different departments(fraud , travel, opening, commercial) screen calls when I was internally trying to get help for clients. They all would NOT take calls unless they would get credit for their metrics by, Using filter questions before they would accept a call internally. 5) When issues arise company asked all reps to document and obtain coding, all the analytic work to solve your issues that Operations Analysts are not doing, you are expected to document this all while your talking to a Card Member or counting against you while you are in after call waiting time counting against your metrics. 6)The Company Campaign that they are "Putting the Customer First " in Aug. 2018 has not changed, the Amex culture is very disturbingly embedded of a culture of commission incentives, is still, as I left the company April 29th 2021. 7) Company allows you to uses your sick time and PTO that they load in the beginning of the year of 120hrs and TL's approve time for CCPs like candy when sick time of 90hr is not being use appropriately as sick time, 99% of sick time is used as a personal time request and managers put it in for reps. creating a very volatile workplace and not consistent hours works by employees a violation of company reporting standards to regulators.

headline: Good resume builder, but probably not for long term
pros: Good work-life balance and work from home flexibility. Colleagues are generally smart and motivated. AmEx is more transparent in terms of policies when compared to other financial services companies, and they try to treat employees well. They try their best to put the customer first.
cons: Many folks are leaving. Every day I get multiple notification emails that people are moving on. Morale is low. Compensation is really not competitive for today's market, and there were no raise increases for 2021. In the last couple of years it's been very apparent that people are coming here just to get the company name on the resume, take advantage of the long parental leave, and move on. Unless you have a family and a very long commute, where the work-life balance is extremely important, chances are that you will probably not be incentivized to stay for a long time. As others have mentioned, upward mobility is very difficult and pay increases are minimal, even when they are given.

headline: Team culture is everything
pros: The company culture is great: very flexible work/life balance, access to mental health resources, commitment to I&D, employee engagement events and extensive parental leave
cons: Team culture drives more of the day-to-day experience than the company culture, so the director or VP of a team can make or break your experience. It doesn’t help that they tend to value tenure over hard work, so “Amex Lifers” get in positions of power who are often complacent and lack any interest in innovation or change.

headline: A good experience to have in CV but not for a long term job
pros:
- a big company that you can learn a lot or build your connection with other colleagues from various departments, they often have cross-department events or groups
- they respect the staffs overall
- salary is above average as a customer service role in HK, with good package such as medical insurance
cons:
- work shifts
- very stressful because they spoil their members very much (due to the nature of the job), they do not have a decent database,  system is old-fashioned, not many supportive partners in the list, hardly to find support to fulfil the requests
- basically you are like a personal assistance, one day the boss asked you to book a restaurant that no one can ever get a table for on day dinner, the next day he said he wanted you to do whatever researches. topics are always unexpected, you have to use your own way to solve problems for the bosses and they seldom appreciate what you did because they think AE can do everything, if you cannot do it by the timeline they set? they give bad feedback 
- cannot see the future for this role, there is no technique or skills and working experience here is basically just a call centre job nothing special. it sounds cool to be a lifestyle manager, but actually you use google to search everything like everyone else can do. getting bored and tired very easily.
- nearly no promotion chance even you have a good performance consistently, they would have a lot of ''reasons'' to tell you why (of course if you think twice, the reasons are not valid...), and just chose someone they like to be friend with. And they do not really care about operation, many agents did not follow standard of procedures and leaders just care about the KPI, but bare in mind that this is a financial institute...

I would say this is good to have an experience in this company for your CV, but if you are looking for a career instead of a job, my advise is do not stay in this role for more than 1year or you are just wasting your time, unless you really enjoy playing mind games with the clients.

headline: Great company, challenging from a mobility perspective
pros: Amex really backs their employees - no one was laid off in 2020 despite the pandemic, and we were told that early on, which was amazing from a job security perspective. PTO policies are incredibly generous, and WFH flexibility was the norm long before COVID. There are great interest networks you can join to meet people outside your business unit, and on the whole, most people are intelligent, collaborative, and friendly. Steve (CEO) is likeable, honest, and his priorities seem to shift with that of his employee base (e.g. a strong emphasis on D&I in 2020 and beyond).
cons: Amex pays about 30% below market value against other financial institutions. It is also incredibly challenging to get promoted at Amex, and you often get stuck in a role for much longer than you'd like. Even when you do get promoted, there are VERY stringent guidelines about compensation attached to promotions, so it's hard to secure a significant raise at any given time. The annual review process is also extremely over-complicated.

cons: The rampant use of "contractors" is absurd. It's a caste system where the contractors are treated as second-class citizens. No American Express benefits and minimal to no perks. When something is set up in the lobby, generally it is something for "employees only" (contractors should just on walking). As a contractor, you have no PTO, and no paid holidays. headline: Culture pros and cons.
pros: Receive annual raises for inflation.
cons: Irrational employment ratings if 1 difficult customer with a challenging personality complains/ if another department messes up and the company receives a bad rating. It's unfair. No training to deal with difficult customers and an irrational expectation to have 100% customers happy. Doesn't matter if you have 99% of customers liking you. What matters is how many customers complete your surveys. And that 1 mean customer can highly skew your stats. Yet they don't have training as a whole at the company to teach you how to handle difficult personalities inside the company and outside of the company as you have internal and external customers. Lots of processes are old fashion taking 20 steps when it should only take 5. Extra work and less efficient. But nice in general.

headline: Great work-life, too much red tape
pros:
1. Work-life balance
2. Employee friendly culture
3. Frequent trainings to enhance employee growth
4. Good compensation. The company believes in pay parity and equal gender pay ratio.
cons:
1. Narrow projects. Each team in Amex (at-least within Risk Management) is assigned to work on same projects for a long time. Anyone who wishes to work on diverse projects may start to feel disengaged soon. It is also not that easy to switch teams, as the leaders would like to tell you.
2. Too much red tape. Every minor change is under a lot of scrutiny and requires many levels of approvals. Makes it extremely difficult to challenge the status quo.
3. After a certain level/band, vertical growth becomes stagnant.

headline: Good Company, Terrible Market
pros:
-Brand recognition in your CV: nice stepping stone
-Decent salary and benefits
-Flexible for and remote work policies (check Cons)
-Solid company that has been around for almost 200 years.
-Great brand values (check Cons)
cons:
-Your career path and the flexible policies depend on your leader: some people in one line of business may have flexible hours while some other people, doing a similar job, different LOB or manager, might be enslaved by their leaders or commanded to chair heating. HR is totally out of everything related to promotions, internal movements, career paths, etc. No support at all.
-A lot of managers, a few workers... You know what I mean: one is working, four are watching.
-Leaders do not have a clue about what they are doing. Apart from that, they usually do not get well with data and reports and do not give clear actionable feedback to their teams. You can be wrong at your decisions but at least deliver projects and guide your teams... Is not the case.
-There's no product development for the market, no IT or development resources...
-Self-service culture for everything, from invoicing your activities to hiring new people... You end up buried in administrative tasks.
-Despite company values (standing for equity, inclusion, diversity, supporting some important causes and movements...), the office is full of intolerants and snobs that complain about these values... Honestly, don't understand how they hire but most of the people are unbearable.
-Weird organization: There may be 3 directors for the same area. Some other people earn a lot of money but do nothing (and brag about it). However, hiring a new executive is like asking for a kidney......

headline: Time flies, but does your career?
pros:
-Generous yearly PTO
-Good health benefits,
-Fun colleague promotional events throughout the year
-Flexible work environment,
-Great CEO (he is very candid)
-Getting further in diversity and inclusion for employee groups/events.

Overall, a good place to start your career if you're interested in learning about the company, and enjoy the 9-5 work environment.
cons:
-Bureaucratic ways of management 
-Undervalues hardworking staff,
-Promotes often based on nepotism
-Slow to drive agile mindset across the company
-Lower wages compared to others in the industry, outdated technology, and not all leaders are promoted due to leadership abilities, more overly promoted for technical abilities or overall tenure. It's assumed, the longer you're here, the more you know- this is not always the case.

Buyer beware, if you accept an offer at this company- the furthest you might go comp wise is going to be very dependent on what you enter the company at. In terms of promotions, you must find influential leaders that can help get your name out and support your growth. If they are leaders who might not be as well perceived by their peers, you might not want to be associated with them for too long. 

Program teams have slow movement and multiple meeting requests- it can feel like you're going in circles to accomplish anything . There are alot of bottlenecks when multiple teams have to work together.

headline: Massive finance organization creates a lot of headaches
pros:
Good brand name for the resume
Cool office location
Happy hours
Decent training
cons:
Below-average salaries
Constant restructuring and fear of layoffs
Internal mobility is difficult
The work you do doesn’t matter as much as your “personal brand” and your ability to network within the company; you can’t advance if your VP doesn’t like you
Finance organization is too large with too many teams that do similar things; teams end up competing against each other and sometimes are openly hostile towards one another because of lack of clarity about roles and responsibilities, and because people are protecting their own job security rather than doing what is best for the company
Good chance that you will get siloed and end up only focusing on one or two account lines within the P&L, with no exposure to other things unless you can move internally to a new department

headline: Working during a pandemic

headline: AMEX is the best company to work for.
pros:
They genuinely care for their employees and their personal growth. 
They have tie ups with some really reputed universities so in case you are a drop out, they would love you to continue your studies and thats very important in order for you to do well in your career. 
Even if you don't have a leave balance, for a valid reason like education, health or family emergency, they are always accommodating. The salary does not get deducted at all. 
Amazing leaders and management so there is so much to learn from them. 
They are happy to let the youngest person in the team take on a training project as long as you are capable and have the zeal to grow rather than giving it to someone only because of their seniority. 
Amazing salary + even better incentives.
Work life balance, no stress at all. 
It feels like home.
cons: Choosing the right department or process is very important because there are departments where it is really stressful.

headline: Sales team needs to be prioritized
pros: The best part of working for Amex is knowing that the company you work is an internationally recognized Fortune 500 company. They try their best to ensure to be the best workplace to work for, especially in the Philippines. The benefits are so-so compared to other global companies in PH.
cons: If you're in the sales team, you have to remember that the customer service reps earn more than you do. For a financial company, it seems difficult for the company to give more commission to their sales team. There are also less than average incentives compared to other sales team I worked for, mostly consisting of Amex merchandise such as a notepad or pen for a specific task. Management for the Global Commercial Services in the Philippines is full of office politics which resulted to almost half the team leaving last year. No clear path to career growth unless a position is open. Racism encountered with Australian colleagues who pass work to Philippine employees if they think the task is mundane.

headline: Collaborative culture but career progression and salary is awful
pros: Good culture overall.  People are generally great to work with and many sharp people too. Easily better than other companies I worked at.  If you’re on a big project it can definitely help your career otherwise it’s sink or swim as nobody will focus on what you do.
cons: Given I saw hiring and year end rating processes it is even more frustrating in hindsight how this company focuses on playing favorites and making it incredibly difficult for some people to get promoted while others play the coffee chat culture and move up quickly while just delivering their work.  On top of that the salary is absolutely mediocre compared to other companies in NYC, especially in financial services.  Stay here too long and you’ll forget that companies are giving you total comp packages that are a minimum of 20% more for the SAME job level. Yet for a promotion here, I had to fight for a 8% increase and I wasn’t at the top range of my level.   Come here for a couple of years for the mat/pat leave benefit and get out ASAP.

headline: Highly Engaged and Supportive Culture
pros: Long-term, American Express will take care of their employees. Between cash bonuses, profit-sharing, and 401k match, there is a reason why my colleagues have spent 10+ years with the company. There are always trainings being offered to acquire new skills as well as programs to loan employees to other business areas in order to gain exposure. Lastly, hierarchy, at least where I am, exists only on paper. I have gotten as much 1-on-1 time with my VP as I have my director as I have my manager. If you seek to make connections, your efforts will be rewarded.
cons: As with any large company, understanding where there are opportunities to advance your career can be difficult to find and navigate. There are resources to help, but not really guides on how to properly use those resources. If you work on a global team, rather than one that is based in a country, figuring out how to advance without completely relocating can be challenging.

headline: Cultural failure, incompetent leadership and business operations
pros:
- Lenient work from home policy (until that got restricted). It was nice only coming into the office three times/ week. Then my manager changed the policy to coming into office 4 times/week.
- Interesting work to some degree
cons:
- Very little resources and a high-stress environment. Expect like 5 engineers coming to you at once for help because they are too lazy to read documentation or figure it out on their own. This can happen non-stop for an entire week.
- Production outages here and there. Be prepared to drop your current task just to fix some random issue.
- There is culture of fear. Also, superiors will inappropriately touch you and engage in other degrading conduct such as harassment, fist slamming and yelling at you.
- Coworkers will speak in Indian around you, they tend to stick with their own groups so there isn't really an inclusive culture.
- Very low pay for Bay Area.

headline: Great to work but not 100% perfect

-Pay equity. Women get paid the same as men, per an annual third-party audit of salaries.
-Good benefits, including 5 months paid parental leave
-Very satisfied with my salary
-Seems to sincerely care about diversity, though sometimes the efforts miss the mark
-Has had an incredible response to the COVID pandemic. Has put the employees first every step of the way.
cons:
-very little mentorship opportunities for band 30 engineers (entry to mid-level engineers)
-still has some very 'bro'-like ways of evaluating engineers. The 'bros' are the ones who tend to excel. Anyone else falls by the wayside.
-female engineers need quality feedback from the leaders and accountability just like male engineers
-if you are lgbt or have no interest in having children, there's no great benefits for you as a counterpart to the parental leave. So get ready to have to cover for your teammates for 5 months at a time over and over and over again and get nothing in return.

headline: Smoke and mirrors
pros: Excellent compensation, especially if you get the bonus. Insane amounts of PTO (7 weeks, the let you 'buy' an extra week)
cons:
I could write a novel on the cons. I was hired as an engineer, but I haven't written code longer than five lines since I started here. We just slap spreadsheets into tables, and voila! we're engineers.

Our leader is unable to make and adhere do a decision and severely lacks leadership skills. It has taken us nearly one full year to build a report portal. This is something that could have been done by a group of high school kids in a few weeks.

Trying to bring in external tools to make our jobs more efficient is nearly impossible. The red tape is so thick, it would be faster to build your own operating system than try to buy useful software.

The group I work for seems to want to find problems for their solutions instead of solving actual business problems. I heard a funny term, "resume driven development".

As mentioned in other reviews, AMEX is not a place to grow your skills, but a place to get complacent and cash checks. If you're eager to learn, grow, and do amazing things, keep looking. This is not the place for growth. If you're close to retiring and want to put your feet up on your desk for 7.5 hours a day, welcome aboard.

Someone from the project management team will come up with a "brilliant new idea" and you'll just have to oblige, even if, as a frontline employee, you already know it won't work. Then six months later, they'll just drop it and come up with a new idea. Team leaders are so desperate to please their own managers, there isn't a lot of support. Saying that, if you're happy to do as you're told without questioning any decision, you'll do just fine! It's just not for everybody

headline: Bad experience due to toxic management
pros: Good brand name to be associated with, pays above market rate, very good employment benefits (health, medical & wellness), good job security, opportunity to make lateral moves and work in other Amex offices in the world, very advance in digital, fast-paced and very innovative, new things to learn everyday even though processes can be a little haphazard but it's something you should take upon yourself to rectify.
cons:
Progression is slow (3-5 years for a promotion), extreme top-down work culture so everyone at the bottom is just scared of the people on top, and those in the middle (managers) are just messengers between the analysts & senior management, with no real value-add.

I was unfortunate to have a toxic manager & director which made me miserable during my 2 years at Amex. My team mates felt the same way and left for the same reason. The team that replaced us is now also feeling the same way and planning to leave too (so I know I wasn't an isolated case).

If I wasn't so unfortunate, I would have loved to stay longer.

Although I would still recommend working at Amex to friends, I will highly discourage anyone from joining my ex-team.

headline: One of the best places to work for
pros:
Working at American Express is a privilege. Employee satisfaction is one of the big blue box values for the management. Colleagues are extremely courteous, super helpful. You can literally go up to anyone no matter their destination and have a discussion. 
Everyone is proud of the company and take blue box values very seriously. I work in technology and Amex is no less than other niche tech giants. You are encouraged to innovative, and most importantly, heard by the upper management. Amex offers most competitive salary in the market with dozens of perks and privileges, so you know, your organization has your back in good and bad days. Moreover it is super flexible with work timing and locations. Ample work from homes and leaves are provided, so work life balance isn't an issue. No doubt it ranks in fortune top 10 places to work for.
cons: Not much of cons here, but not all the teams work on exciting projects. But you can change teams in 18 months, so that's no issue.

headline: Awesome place to work with great folks/management
pros:
Most managers/coworkers are extremely friendly and helpful, and are frequently responsible for mentoring new hires or junior developers 
You can really feel that those in charge genuinely want to help their employees; benefits are excellent, accepting and friendly culture is constantly reinforced/encouraged, community events (at least in NYC) are consistent and open to all employees, cross-organization learning sessions are common. 
Salary is fairly competitive, especially for locations outside of NYC (not to say that NYC salaries are low though)
Excellent work/life balance, and the company is constantly improving its agile methodology/workflow to ensure working late on the job is a thing of the past
cons: Career growth can be limited within a team, especially larger ones - you may need to apply to positions in other organizations for promotions. If you want to stay in your team, you need to constantly push your boss for raises/promotions as they aren't likely to come to you naturally (which isn't necessarily uncommon across various companies)

headline: Too number focused for Gen Y employees
pros:
Coworkers are great - they are always willing to help you. I ended up meeting awesome people there.  

They have a Tim Hortons coffee machine. 

Very good pay for a 1st job if you have recently graduated or if you are a newcomer (considering you lend on a bilingual position). 

Health benefits from day 1. Insurance is good overall...
cons:
Work hours are definitely not the usual 9-5. Everyone needs to engage working on a weekends and stat holidays. 

No work from home flexibility. 

Too much talk about your numbers. The way they talk about it is not motivating at all - it's just an endless pressure, as if you didn't reach your numbers on the first weeks of job training, "something would happen". 

They have this certification thingy going on for new hires. People have to worry about their 3 month probation period PLUS about getting "certified". They talk about it as if it was a degree or something like that. Guys, this is not University...

People talk about about career opportunities but I'm not sure I've seen this happening to my coworkers that have been working there for many many years. You do get a chance to moving from one department to the other (credit, new accounts, etc.), but at the end of the day you are still over the phone. I'm not sure how that plays out. 

However, Indo have to say that working at Amex is way better than working at several other places.

headline: Balance
pros:
-Great Culture (depends on team)
-Amazing work life balance (depends on team)
-Real work learning opportunities such as coding (SQL/Python)
-Upwards mobility specially if coming in as a Analyst/Sr. analyst

Over all an amazing company to work in. Although some things depend on what team you are in, my Pros apply to most of the company. Have not really seen bad culture/work life balance teams, but have heard of them through word of mouth. Great learning Financial Service opportunity without the hyper A Personality culture of the industry.
cons:
-PTO days do lack a little when starting as an Analyst. Due to the fact that holidays must be taken from your PTO totals. Also PTOs do not roll over or get paid out (You can buy PTOs and you get your money back if not used during the year). For me this balances out due to the work life balance I have.
-Health insurance has a high deductible even when getting the most expensive (even then not too expensive if Single or Married). This does balance out by being offered a HSA which the company contributes a sum at beginning of each year (which depend on your doctor would cover your copays).
-Layoffs and Reorgs. Like many companies you hear of layoffs and Reorgs which suck and it is a con. What many people do not tell you is that Layoffs usually occur at VP or higher levels and a Reorg usually gets a couple months notice and a package if you do not find anything. Again does not feel good if you end up in this situation (and hope I never have to be in it), but it is not like the movies where the same day you pack your things and go.

headline: Rampant Discrimination
pros: Work-life balance, onsite gym and cafeteria, good lineup of guest speakers, affinity groups, occasional free food
cons:
Blatant discrimination, racism, cronyism, pay below industry average, outdated technology, old fashioned, little innovation, bureaucratic, very slow decision making, the opposite of Agile. 

I was told that the diversity at Amex was a facade when I first started. I ignored the warning and didn't believe that an industry leader such as Amex could partake in discriminatory and exclusionary practices. There's a reason that discrimination is mentioned in Glassdoor reviews. It's prevalent. Amex claims diversity and inclusion in their Glassdoor intro and beyond for marketing and recruitment efforts only. They're checking a box because it's trendy and upheld by law, but there's nothing done in practice. HR does nothing to stop discrimination when reported and will protect their racist managers even when showing proof of discrimination and harassment.  The racial tension that's on display throughout the country right now is alive and well at Amex. You'll be shocked by the amount of stories that you'll hear about former employees leaving because of the discrimination they faced while working there. This is the reality. You've been warned.

headline: Very poorly organised team by inexperienced managers
pros:
Friendly team members
Fairly interesting work
working from home options
cons:
Constant changes and decision making by management, promoting people with no management experience who then make a hash of things but the team gets the blame for work not in a certain style that hadn't been directed clearly,  while 2 people (33%) down and thus stretched already. This happens a lot because they are too slow to retain people who then line up new jobs and leave, who would have been asked to stay longer. 

They love to start people on fixed contracts, fine - but dont then offer an extension (this time agreed) only to pull it at the last minute citing poor performance. When challenged on why an extension has been offered if performance is so bad, newly promoted manager blames the other manager saying "he didnt have time (6 months!) to check your work and realise its poor" what a load of rubbish! Plus this, despite the VP giving regular positive feedback over the period and agreeing the contract extension. 
Said manager was promoted after 5 years as a team member and began to throw her weight around, the whole team agreed after just a week she was verging on bullying. One of the best things about being led up the garden path with a contract extension, only to have it mysteriously pulled, was not having to report to her any longer. It was a classic case of someone being good technically, so getting promoted, but then having zero management ability and a big ego. Seemed to be no support from VP to get her settled into the role properly and reign her in.

headline: Great Place to Work, Great Benefits, Excellent Colleagues
pros:
1. Beautiful AMEX Campus here in South Florida right next to Sawgrass mall. The Campus has lots of amenities for Colleagues like the state of art infrastructure, games, healthy living cafe, onsite clinic which provides a very impressive range of health services, activity center (yoga, meditation, mindfulness and more), kids care center and more...
2. Excellent place to work & learn for all - Technology, Product, Customer Care  
3. If you aspire to work in the latest technologies like Machine Learning, AI, Robotics, Big Data, React  and many more, then this is the place to be. If you are interested in Customer Servicing, then this is the best place to be.
4. Culture at AMEX is very vibrant, creative, collaborative and friendly. Very diversified organization. You can find people from all across the globe working here.
5. Great benefits to the Colleagues. Great Leadership. Great Work / Life Balance.
cons:
1. Like any other large organization, there are challenges here too. But if you are determined to solve the real problems, then you will get the support you need. But you need to be patient and work to overcome those challenges.
2. Health Insurance costs / benefits can be better. They are not bad, but there is room for improvement.

headline: Exciting time to be working in Technology at American Express.
pros:
- Truly attempts to uphold what Amex calls "Blue Box Values". Not just lip-service.
- With recent transformations especially using the Technology-first approach, the company has molted from its state in the first decade of the millennium. 
- Like with any very large global corporation, cannot expect the agility of a startup but company places very high value on agility and speed of decision making.
- You are treated as a person, not just a body with a brain and hands.
- Senior management takes employee feedback seriously.
cons:
- Very large matrixed global multinational (couple more adjectives) corporation. Makes it a challenge to get a grasp on the who's-who in the company.
- Being a bank-holding company, technology decision making does get impeded due to strict government regulations around the finance sector.

headline: This is a tough gig that requires you to be sharp and present on every call.
pros:

-Incentive/Commission structure (payouts)
-Employee Benefits are one of the best you’ll find 
-The Sunrise facility has a lot of nice resources such as cafeteria, lounge/game areas, fitness space, daycare, Starbucks, and concession areas
-On-site nurse, physical therapist, and more things that I’m probably not aware of.
cons: Customer service call centers are high-speed, high-stress environments and every move you make is being coded and recorded towards a compliance metric. Something as simple as taking off your headset to go to the restroom at your own discretion is not so simple at AMEX. You’re taking 50-80 calls a day and when you’re making that much contact with different people all over the country with their own issues and sass , it can be overwhelming, exhausting, and daunting.

headline: Bureaucratic, slow-moving, traditional and conservative but good brand name
pros:
-Amex is a good brand name and helps you learn how to navigate a traditional and conservative culture
-There are mentorship opportunities and open culture of coffee chats, which makes it easy to learn what others are doing and what you might want to do in the future
-I truly think people are the greatest asset here, they are collaborative and helpful though there are always those few who will do anything to move forward
cons:
-Most bureaucratic company I have been in so far and I have worked in several fortune 100's
-Everything is so slow moving, no one wants to make or own a decision. I am all for collaboration, but not to the detriment of things never moving, it really hurts your ambition
-Very few people want to challenge the status quo so they continue to do things as they have always been done with no desire for innovation, and most of the time, it is not the most efficient or effective way to do it
-I am shocked at how de-centralized data is though they are working on it..it is an extremely traditional place to work in
-The meeting culture is extreme, it is meeting after meeting after meeting and nothing moves forward
-Many leaders are promoted due to tenure or networking but are not effective leaders at all, it is honestly a hit or miss
-I was really excited to be part of Amex but it has honestly been a disappointment on so many levels
-Amex pays grossly below market and promotions are slow to come

Your metrics are your leader's metrics as well and as such they do not have any incentive to lead you to other roles - its sad. cons: During my interview, I was told that there is "unlimited income potential".  What they didn't tell me is that AmEx keeps moving the bar further away as you get closer to the finish line.  The metrics are unfair and unrealistic to earn a regular bonus.  Every customer gets an opportunity to submit a survey, however, the LAST AmEX employee to speak to the customer, during each call, is upon whom the survey falls.  Therefore, if the customer speaks to collections first, and gets angry during the call, then collections transfers the call to you to discuss having misplaced their credit card, everything they say in the angry survey is credited to YOU.  One survey with a "poor" rating will cause you to lose your entire bonus for a rolling 3 month period!  Another unfair metric is counted when you assist a customer and they call again within 7 days.  Even if the customer calls back for a totally different reason, the fact that they called at all within 7 days means you did not properly assist them.  For example, if the customer calls you to pay their bill, then 3 days later calls again for a password reset, THAT is counted against YOU because the customer called back within 7 days.  This, too, counts against your bonus.  Further, there are no assigned workspaces.  Seating is in a first-come-first-selected area.  You are assigned a locker for your personal belongings, but change desks from shift-to-shift.  The workspace is approximately 20x40 with only a small panel between each desk.  That, coupled with changing each day, makes the area unsanitary, and presents a high risk of illness due to spreading germs.

headline: Great work culture; need to back off on the multi-level approvals
pros:
- Amex has one of the best work culture. There are always "activities" to keep employees engaged. I love that we can bring ourselves to work, unlike other companies where you have to act a certain way. However, there are disadvantages to this - some people forget that they're in a professional environment and should act with respect and (real) courtesy. 
- The benefits are great. 
-  The Corporate Social Responsibility team does a great job raising awareness, acting on its commitments, and pushing employees to give back to their communities through service or donations. However, I would like to see Amex go beyond sustainability initiatives.
cons:
- "Alignment" is a term that I never thought I would hate. Everything (even the most minuscule thing) has to be reviewed by each level before it can go out. This delays projects and is rather counterproductive, but yet Amex continues to do it. 
- This year, the company launched a campaign that focuses on the employee culture. It's supposed to include internal, but at the moment is focused on external applicants and sharing "why is great to work at Amex". I haven't seen much benefits so far. 
- There are too many tenured employees. While they do bring value, there's not enough out-of-the-box thinking or fresh perspective. Everyone speaks in Amex-speak, which can come off as cultish.
- It is very hierarchical - I've never seen a company so fixated on hierarchy. I would never recommend, with experience, come in as an Analyst because the benefits suck - like they have less vacation days (WTH). Fortunately,  they're now finally eligible for bonuses.
- I get strategy change, but Amex takes re-orgs to another level. In my less than 2 years at Amex, there have been many re-orgs. I'm anticipating there will be a big one based on movements. 
- The salary is lower in comparison to  similar companies. The bonus is not bad.

headline: Great job! Stay for as long as you desire.
pros:
Great benefits, paternity/maternity leave. Cafeteria is one of the best I've been to.

Job security is decent. Be a top performer and you will never need to worry. Also they love it/value when people stay in the same field for 20+ years. They treat you well.

It is a good starting point at American Express.

Vacation time is a nice amount if Full-time.

They are good at meeting you where they can. The minimum, average, and maximum hourly pay is accurate on Glassdoor. So negotiate.

Potlucks and parties are good. Co-workers really make the days go by faster.

You can move to a different department after 12 months (see cons).
cons:
Unfortunately, if you want to move to a different department it is hard. Leaders/Managers will get discouraged and possibly jealous if they hear you want to move. Be tight lipped if that is your goal. Seen too many people passed on for leadership roles because they mentioned they want to move to other departments.

Leaders do not like it when you discover things sooner than them or know more than them. They get intimidated, which is human. 

Hours can be tough if you lose out on shift bids. 

Good luck taking off on major holidays.

If you dream of more than answering calls all day, this career path may not be for you. 

Some people have MBAs, MAs, BAs, or Associates. Some people have life experience. Some people have little to no experience. All are paid the same.

A new recruit can surpass you in a few months because seniority is not important anymore. Performance is the new seniority. 

No discounts on cards.

headline: Sr. Manager, Business Development
pros:
Amazing culture and great benefits. The pay is also competitive and you get to work remote. All necessary work equipment is provided by the company (laptop, printer, docking station, monitor, etc). The job requires you to travel to meet with existing clients but the company either pays for your mileage or they allow you to rent a car. 

Management has been terrific, in my experience. I feel like my directors and VPs have my back and I don’t live in fear of termination if I have a slow month or quarter. Leadership is good about being transparent when change occurs and they set clear expectations. They are also really good about setting time for 1:1 calls and making themselves available when needed. This is important because working remote can sometimes be a challenge when you need help or have a question. 

The final thing I’ll say is that the paid time off is very generous (and you can buy more) and the company doesn’t let your PTO roll over into the next calendar year. This is amazing because it encourages people to take their PTO without guilt or fear of backlash.
cons: The only cons I can think of are the standard ones that come from working with a big company. Change is slow and sometimes doesn’t make a whole lot of sense.

headline: Trying to be the Google of the FINTECH world
pros: Work-Life balance,  benefits are on par with the banking/financial industry,  but salaries are hit or miss.  If you sell yourself short coming into the company it's going to be difficult to obtain industry norms.
cons:
They've gone from a relatively cautious, adverse organization to pretend like they're some bleeding edge Silicon Valley powerhouse.   Some fresh out of college "consultant" recommendations rewriting the core authorization platform (currently written in Assembly language) in Go and leadership takes it under serious consideration.  LOL!!!  Really? 

Again, they're trying to be something they're not and that spells disaster for the "workers" that have to "tow the line" to meet unrealistic demands while dealing with constant reorgs and cost cutting initiatives.  It used to be that Lead Programmer Analysts should be SMEs and team leaders that didn't code much at all.  Now, even the VPs are expected to be able to write code and pass coding exams if applying  from outside of the company  and that is just a tad ridiculous.  

One thing holds true;  AMEX is a GREAT place to work.....IF you end up in the right group.

headline: German speaking Credit Specialist - Brighton
pros:
- Your colleague’s will often be nice and interesting people, which helps ‘survive in the jungle’
- Company benefits
cons:
- No ownership of your time and work flow
- No space for personal input
- Strict application of processes 
- No spectrum for personal development
- Awful management 

You will be working in a call centre environment, so be prepared to have to justify yourself if you need a personal break. Your entire activity will be controlled and monitored by ‘metrics of productivity’ which are in fact counter productive, since you can’t expect people to function like robots. 

Obviously this is not something my hiring manager told me in the interview otherwise I’d never ever have taken the job. 

She sold it to me as a client relationship management role which is a very different thing. A lot of things will be promised to you in the interview, as they are so desperate to find people to do this job. Very few of these things will be true and that’s a hard reality to swallow once you realise it.  Within the 9 months I stayed in the role, 14 people have come and go and that tells a lot. To justify this they’ll come up with excuses such as ‘the millennial generation’ - hilarious!!!

Good luck to apply for another role that would suit you better: you’ll suddenly hear about a 12 month rule that stops you from applying for another role. If you eventually you get your ‘Leader’s’ approval to attend the interview, she’ll come up with the last minute excuse that HR have opposed to it. Well, if you call HR they’ll tell you that you could attend it, with your leader’s approval.
I let you make-up your mind on this one.

Again, good luck if you can stand all that non-sense and make a request to work one day less. You will be asked to give reasons for that and be prepared, ‘improve your work life balance and personal well-being’ given how monotonous and repetitive your work is wont be enough. Your lovely ‘Leadership Team’ might well want to refer you to occupational health, because they’re concerned you might have mental health issues - wtf!? 

This was probably the worse experience of my career. Awful management. It gave me nightmares and caused me a lot of stress. That’s not a place where you’ll develop your skills and grow your career. Good if you have no plans, I guess it pays the bills. If you’re ambitious, avoid the place at all costs. Still thinking about what this experience brought me and I can’t think of anything except a waste of my valuable time and I’m so glad I left.

headline: All that glitters isn't gold
pros: Nothing from my experience.
cons:
Amex used to be my dream company and I was extremely happy when I joined almost 8 months back. Soon I realised it was a huge mistake!

1. The work life balance highly depends on your manager and teammates. In my case, the situation is really, really bad. I devote extra hours in the night as well as on weekends.

2. I expected to get some recognition after all the hard work that I've been doing, but all I get is more work and complete neglect from the manager. I've raised this concern to him several times, but every time he questions me about what work I've done even though he is the one who directly assigns projects to me. 
 
3. Even after being an FTE here, I get less flexibility in terms of work-from-home and shift timings as compared to the vendor resources. Moreover, they are free to take as many leaves as they want, since my manager doesn't care to check their inputs and logs. Every little work is pushed on to me.

4. I can easily see and prove that I have accomplished more work than any of my teammates, but not a single word of appreciation has come my way. On the other hand, even those who openly boast about taking long holidays for leisure trips are lauded for petty things.

5. At Amex, the HR doesn't exist. There's no exit interview for employees who are leaving and they don't even have the right to mention the reason for resigning. The director will write whatever reason he wants. There's nobody an employee can go to if the director isn't listening to his or her problems. 

6. In my team, only 2-3 people who are close to the director will get farewell party or b'day celebration. For others, the teammates and the director won't even realise that they're missing until some work comes up. This has created an atmosphere where everyone is buttering the director. Sincerety and hard work hold no value here.

headline: I worked for American Express as a Travel Counselor (home base) Difficult customers that feel like Queens
pros: The only good thing about the company is the compensation. They do pay you well as a Travel Counselor . But you become a prisoner at your own home . Not worth the money .
cons:
Hiring process was ok . The training was long , is about 12-14 weeks long .They cover so much unnecessary information , I feel like some parts of the training are useless and they don’t prepare you in any way for the real job . They want you to participate in class so be prepared for instructor to call your name if you’re quiet . Listen & Interact and you will make it . 

During end of training most our classmates wanted to listen to recorded calls so we could see the the flow of a call . They were never able to provide  a call from beginning to end with a a screen . They could only provided a few sloppy calls where they were just short & no screen just audio and not even a sale . We couldn’t believe that a company as big as Amex couldn’t provide a decent recorded call .They weren’t able to provide a clear  understanding on how metrics & surveys works. (It was probably our team lead who wasn’t well informed) . 

When you start taking calls be prepare to deal with customers who feel like they’re the queens . Some would talk down to you & be super rude . Most of the calls are from members who are well traveled and know what they want . You’re just an order taker , also be prepare to deal with multiple different systems at the same time .(always slow and crash often) you’re not allow to tell customers our system doesn’t work but you’re not allow for dead air . Customer don’t care to chat they would keep asking you to hurry up because they don’t have time . Also be ready to deal with rude employees.  if they’re training you they would talk to you as if you were 5 year old . You can also find them in other departments. They would just hang up on you or wound school you for “not doing your job “ correct .

headline: Consensus Culture to the Extreme
pros: If you are a person who lives for good benefits and job security, this company is for  you. If you pride yourself as innovative and an independent thinker, run as far as you can.
cons: American Express is a private club, not only for its card members, but for its employees. It is a mutual admiration society, and on most days, resembles an incestuous clique. If you are part of the right team, and should be lucky to find a good leader, then all is well. If you find yourself on a team where you don't fit in, you will suffer a lot, as it is a consensus culture where your ideas will not be respected unless ALL members of your team agrees. The by-product of this culture is SUPER SLOW BUSINESS SPEED and total LACK OF INNOVATION.  They always promote from within, so its the same people in 12 different roles and titles. Same boring ideas, same pat on the back for mediocre group think.  Leaders are generally poor quality, even though they are forced to go through this Harvard leadership certificate program (most don't even show up to class or do their work but get the certificate anyway). There are few opportunities to move up as everyone stays around forever because of the benefits.
